title: Roth Score for Hypoxia Screening
desc: The Roth Score screens for hypoxia in dyspneic patients.

orgreference.text: Chorin E, Padegimas A, Havakuk O, et al. Assessment of Respiratory Distress by the Roth Score. Clin Cardiol. 2016;39(11):636-639.

data.evidence:
Instruct patient:

  1. Take a deep breath.

  2. In your native language, count clearly from 1 to 30 out loud, as fast as possible without stopping, until you are either out of breath or reach 30.

Clinician: Time how many seconds it takes the patient to reach 30, or until they must take another breath.

Also, record the highest number they can reach before they have to take another breath. 

Watch a primary care physician in the UK describe the Roth Score on Youtube.
data.facts:
Interpretation:

Risk based on maximum number reached before next breath

<10

91% sensitive for O₂ sat <95%

<7

87% sensitive for O₂ sat <90%

>10

Roth score less suggestive of hypoxia (but at higher numbers the score appears to be less sensitive for hypoxia)

Risk based on total seconds counted before next breath

<7

83% sensitive for O₂ sat <95%

<5

82% sensitive for O₂ sat <90%

>7

Roth score less suggestive of hypoxia (but at higher numbers the score appears to be less sensitive for hypoxia)

Note: Medical conditions, overall gestalt, and risk should be taken into consideration by the treating clinician.
